author: sky.cactus
content:
<@!543900561460822016> re: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2929#pullrequestreview-479896831
> I left a few style related comments here, but looks like I was too late
when I review and merge like that, I would *rather* leave it to the author to merge when they are ready.  This allows me to leave optional feedback, as well as gives time for other editors to leave a review.

author: sky.cactus
content: Would be nice if the auto-merge bot could be setup such that once I approve the PR, then the author can (at their leisure) tell the bot to merge (either via command or approval or something).

author: sky.cactus
content: If you have ideas on how to do that as the EIP bot master that would be awesome.  üò¨

author: lightclient
content: That‚Äôs possible with a bors-like system! You basically just yield merge control to the author via a comment

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!543900561460822016> Can we get the EIP validator to automatically check this?  <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2930#discussion_r481279214>

author: lightclient
content: will fix

author: axic3354
content: Was the question regarding ordering of the requires field resolved?

author: axic3354
content: Some used it as incrementing order, others as importance.

author: lightclient
content: i'm not sure what the result of that conversation was, but `eipv` requires they are in ascending order ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

author: lightclient
content: happy to remove if that is desired, my preference is ascending order though

author: axic3354
content: good with me üôÇ

author: lightclient
content: <@!301186049323958275> the file `2930.md` is in the root dir rather than `EIPS`, that's why the validator didn't fail on the malformed requires

author: axic3354
content: That's a common mistake in today's "rapid merge" environment :trollface:

author: lightclient
content: this could be quickly checked via CI, i'll see if I can make a PR to address this

author: axic3354
content: What exactly would you check?

author: lightclient
content: I'm thinking doing a check if any files in the root dir match `eip-x.md` format, except the template

author: axic3354
content: Oh, perhaps just sweep every directory recursively and if there's a frontmatter consider it an EIP.

author: axic3354
content: And then add an exception for the template.

author: lightclient
content: that works too!

author: axic3354
content: Btw, I think I would personally prefer to give a few days for each new PR before it is merged, to get some initial feedback. In many cases authors will keep pushing tiny changes, and this early merge results in number inflation... I know, we should just move off this number assignment system, I have been complaining about it since forever.

author: lightclient
content: <@!425279588009246720> any thoughts on a separate repo / folder for "early drafts", similar to how "internet drafts" come before "RFCs"?

author: axic3354
content: I thought about just prefixing drafts with `D` and have their of numbering.

author: axic3354
content: And they would be independently numbered (and not just dropping the prefix upon finalisation) so if someone keeps referring to `D77` that is fine, but indicates to the reader they are referring to some incomplete stuff.

author: axic3354
content:
The naming adopted by RFCs/ICPs is quite long and I think the whole process is quite different to what EIPs try to do.

EIPs try to nurture a rapid innovation process, preferring tiny adjustments over large changes.

RFCs on the other hand tend to cover large bodies of specification designed over a long period of time, as opposed to smaller incremental changes.

author: axic3354
content: Honestly I think having some kind of a WYSWYG markdown editor integrated into some "EIP" website is the ultimate solution. Would also keep "pro access" for those who feel confident avoiding the interface. One which takes care of the process. Otherwise, as is currently, no matter how we twist the rules, people will struggle with git, formatting, where to put discussion URLs, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> we should just move off this number assignment system
<@!425279588009246720> What number assignment system?  The EIP number?

author: axic3354
content: Especially as all this revolves around a github repo, it seems to be commonplace (and I have been guilty of it) that people fork the repo, put in the file, maybe open a PR or maybe not, but link to their repository for a proper rendered version. And open multiple discussion URLs. And discussions also happen on each of the PRs. A complete nightmare.

author: sky.cactus
content: We aren't going to run out anytime soon...

author: axic3354
content:
> <@!425279588009246720> What number assignment system?  The EIP number?
<@!301186049323958275> Yes, I proposed the number could be assigned manually (not based on PR number) or by a contract.

The latter option is not the best in today's atmosphere üòâ

author: axic3354
content: I really despise the race for vanity numbers, and number inflation to a smaller extent. There have been so many people doing it...

author: sky.cactus
content: ü§î  I believe I'm ambivalent to how numbers are chosen.  I have only seen a few vanity number grabs, and I wouldn't mind just shutting those down when they happen by skipping the number or something.

author: axic3354
content: Would be also okay codifying some kind of "retorsion" for those committing inflation for vanity numbers üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content:
> I think I would personally prefer to give a few days for each new PR before it is merged
> 
> any thoughts on a separate repo / folder for "early drafts", similar to how "internet drafts" come before "RFCs"?
My concern is that we don't have a good process for making sure EIPs *actually* get looked at.  I follow the repository via email, for example, and if I don't deal with an EIP when it hits my inbox the chances of me merging it later are very low.  If we had some mechanism for "approve today, merge later" I would be OK with a delay though.

author: sky.cactus
content: That being said, it is unclear to me what problem we are solving.  I really don't see a problem with EIP numbers being 5 or 6 digits, and I don't think waiting a few extra days to merge is going to change that either.

author: axic3354
content: I don't use email notifications, only the notification interface on github, so I'm not affected by this. Also tend to do a sweep every now on then instead.

author: axic3354
content: The numbering is maybe just a personal pet peeve, and it may not be important.

author: sky.cactus
content: Historically (and a big part of the reason I accepted the offer to become an editor) EIPs have sat untouched for very long periods of time unless the author pestered the editors.  I really want to make sure we avoid getting into that state again, which is a big part of why I have taken a pretty aggressive approach to merging changes.

author: axic3354
content: If the repo keeps increasing its popularity, it will get to 5 digits soon-ish though.

author: sky.cactus
content: I had a couple EIPs that sat waiting for draft merge and waiting for last call for something like a year.  üò¨

author: axic3354
content: I thought the only pending PRs waiting for a long time were those where authors did not respond in due time.

author: axic3354
content: That is, after the initial "aging time" they suffered during 2016-2018 üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: If I feel confident that we won't fall back into that state, then I don't mind backing off the aggressive merging a bit.  At the moment, I'm concerned that we will fall back into that state if I stop aggressively merging because I know that I won't likely be merging (since my workflow only functions if I respond immediately, no delay) and Axic is the only other editor and I'm not confident at the moment you can keep up solo.

author: axic3354
content: When I had a streak trying to get things in order, I managed to go from ~170 to ~110, then NYE happened. And now we're up over 200 ugh.

author: sky.cactus
content: <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2073> sat waiting for merge to Last Call for over a year.

author: sky.cactus
content: You approved it almost immediately, then it just sat.

author: axic3354
content: I'm not sure what happened there tbh.

author: sky.cactus
content: It wasn't the only one.  üò¢

author: axic3354
content:
But I do have an aversion to Last Call, because I'm uneasy with the process, or what we are trying to accomplish.

I know we are trying to provide a way to establish if a body of text is changing (Draft) or not (Final), but we do not ascertain that it is of any quality or a sufficient* number of eyes have seen it. I think this is what I miss the most, and the Last Call as-it-is is not trying to accomplish any of those goals. As long as it "sat through" the 2 weeks it is final, without anyone ever had a look at it.

In short: it would be nice to enforce some kind of other metric on EIPs getting to the final stage.

author: axic3354
content: Apart from a few examples I could count on my hands, none of the EIPs had any reviews at all when they sat through the last call process.

author: axic3354
content: Not sure if there is any way the above could be accomplished objectively and without requiring way too many resources.

author: sky.cactus
content: I also worry about it not being achievable for a lot of EIPs, and that fact could result in a political problem.

author: axic3354
content: One idea was that the `resolution` field would link to some resources "proving" it.

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone creates some random standard that they believe strongly in but no one else cares about.  They aren't likely to get any eyes on their EIP.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we *require* eyes on EIPs I'm worried we'll end up with people shilling, buying eyes, etc. which is counterproductive.

author: axic3354
content: So for example link to a place where last call discussion was conducted and if it has X number of respondents, then it is deemed to be "interesting enough".

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, if Last Call requires "consensus" then we end up with the opposite problem of people shilling against an EIP to prevent it from being merged.

author: sky.cactus
content: By saying that the author basically gets final say on whether the EIP is done or not, we sidestep having to solve the really hard problems of consensus, quorum, etc.

author: axic3354
content: Btw I think all this goes back to another discussion, which keeps coming up every single time: there should be a Ready or Review state between Draft and Last Call.

author: axic3354
content: Drafts are too fluid, Last Call is "too short".

author: axic3354
content: Or one could argue "major" changes would warrant a new EIP number -- looking at you EIP-1559.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ugh, then we just end up with hundreds or thousands of abandoned EIPs.

author: sky.cactus
content: If your pet peeve is number inflation, my pet peeve is abandoned EIPs living forever.  üòõ

author: axic3354
content: As a person trying to implement core EIPs it is always insanity trying to find what is the current version, what is a given example using, what version are the tests using, etc.

author: axic3354
content: Perhaps one way this could go is that drafts have their own number, a major change warrants a new draft number, once something is finalised it gets a final EIP number.

author: axic3354
content: And drafts are placed in archive, not shown prominently.

author: sky.cactus
content: Draft EIPs do get a unique number per iteration, but it is a number that has a serious number inflation problem... the git commit hash.  üòâ

author: axic3354
content: I'm mostly thinking out loud here.

author: sky.cactus
content: On a more serious note, I think the root of that problem is that people are trying to use draft EIPs as a coordination mechanism, which I don't think is the right place for that.

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO, EIPs are long-term technical standards, not a coordination point for implementers while they iterate on changesets.  I am of the opinion that EIPs should represent what the *author* wants the final spec to look like.

author: axic3354
content:
> On a more serious note, I think the root of that problem is that people are trying to use draft EIPs as a coordination mechanism, which I don't think is the right place for that.

That is the exact reason the PR number assignment, discussion URL, and quick merge was instituted, to be the coordination mechanism for drafts.

author: axic3354
content: Discord is terrible at handling quotes..

author: sky.cactus
content: It is better than it used to be, when it had no quotes.  üò¨

author: sky.cactus
content:
> That is the exact reason the PR number assignment, discussion URL, and quick merge was instituted, to be the coordination mechanism for drafts.
I guess when thinking about this more I'm not actually as hardline against it as I came across above.  I think what I want is to just not have even more process/bureaucracy around iterating on Draft changes than we already have.

author: sky.cactus
content: If people want to coordinate and iterate on the EIP in tandem that is fine, but I dislike this idea of "lets have multiple versions of the same EIP, only one of which will actually make it to final" or the idea of "lets stop updating the EIP with changes that we all agree should happen until everyone catches up with implementations".
